ground_truth: Along the streets, silent faces of the poor wait and watch as a column of black-suited dignitaries carrying branches of laurel passes by. Softly, in time with the drums, the watching people begin to sing, among them Enjolras, Marius, and the radical students. The dignitaries become aware of the singing and glance uneasily from side to side. Into frame comes a team of black horses stepping slowly, black plumes nodding, drawing behind them a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin on its carriage draws level with the students, Enjolras suddenly steps out in front of the horses, waves the red flag, and stops the horses and the procession. The students break the ranks of the crowd and surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students climb onto the top of the carriage, led by Combeferre. Police and national guardsmen control the growing crowds. The crowd supports them and surrounds the coffin carriage, blocking the police's attempts to intervene, singing with passion. Enjolras, the students, and the impassioned crowd have now become the procession. They turn off the main street away from the expected course of the funeral procession. As the procession turns off, the cavalry division gallops ahead and disappears around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over this side street. He slips away through the barricade, which is still rising. Grantaire prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her arms - her favourite sewing armchair - and adds it to the barricade. The barricade is now complete: an impressive wall up to twelve feet high, with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades protect the left and right side of the cafe. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to his little army. Javert, still in his disguise as a rebel, is let back through the guarded 'gate' into the barricaded street. A single flaming torch atop the barricade, caged in by cobbles, underlights a fluttering red flag. They all look up; there's Gavroche, on the top of the barricade. Guns swing round to aim at Javert, who stares back in defiance. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses, bore into the barricade, and wound several men. The red flag falls, the pole sliced through; everyone freezes. Marius brings the torch closer to the powder keg, but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius comes down from the barricade, and as everyone surrounds him in amazement, he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With a struggle, she pulls the letter out of her pocket and pushes it into his hand.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Along the roads, mute visages of the impoverished await and observe as a procession of ebony-attired notables bearing boughs of laurel proceeds by. Gently, in rhythm with the drums, the observing populace commence to chant, among them Enjolras, Marius, and the radical pupils. The dignitaries become conscious of the chanting and gaze anxiously from side to side. Into view comes a team of sable steeds pacing leisurely, dark plumes bobbing, hauling behind them a gun platform adorned in the tricolour banner. As the casket on its carriage aligns with the scholars, Enjolras abruptly steps out in front of the horses, waves the crimson banner, and halts the horses and the parade. The pupils break the lines of the throng and encircle the casket platform. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other scholars ascend onto the peak of the carriage, led by Combeferre. Constables and national guardsmen manage the swelling crowds. The throng backs them and encloses the casket platform, obstructing the constables’ attempts to intervene, singing with fervor. Enjolras, the scholars, and the fervent assemblage have now become the parade. They veer off the primary road away from the anticipated route of the funeral parade. As the procession veers off, the cavalry squadron gallops ahead and vanishes around a bend. Gavroche's pachyderm towers over this side road. He slips away through the blockade, which is still ascending. Grantaire extracts the ultimate piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her embrace - her cherished sewing armchair - and appends it to the blockade. The blockade is now finalized: an imposing barrier up to twelve feet tall, with one heavily fortified portion that can be wheeled open to permit access. Two smaller blockades shield the left and right flank of the café. Enjolras ascends halfway up the principal blockade and turns to his small battalion. Javert, still in his guise as an insurgent, is allowed back through the fortified 'gate' into the barricaded avenue. A solitary blazing torch atop the blockade, caged in by cobbles, illuminates a fluttering crimson banner. They all gaze upward; there's Gavroche, atop the blockade. Firearms pivot to target Javert, who gazes back in defiance. Enjolras confronts Javert as projectiles ricochet off the cornices of the residences, bore into the blockade, and injure several men. The crimson banner tumbles, the pole cleaved through; everyone freezes. Marius brings the torch nearer to the powder keg, but already the soldiers have evacuated. Marius descends from the blockade, and as everyone surrounds him in astonishment, he notices Eponine reclining propped against the blockade. With a struggle, she extracts the note out of her pocket and presses it into his hand.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Along the streets, the silent faces of the poor are waited and watched by a column of black-suited dignitaries carrying branches of laurel passing by. Softly, in time with the drums, a song is begun by the watching people, among them Enjolras, Marius, and the radical students. The singing is made the dignitaries aware of, and they glance uneasily from side to side. Into frame, a team of black horses stepping slowly, with black plumes nodding, comes, drawing behind them a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the students are drawn level with by the coffin on its carriage, Enjolras suddenly steps out in front of the horses, the red flag is waved by him, and the horses and the procession are stopped by him. The crowd's ranks are broken by the students, and they surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students are led by Combeferre onto the top of the carriage. The growing crowds are controlled by the police and national guardsmen. Support is given to them by the crowd, which surrounds the coffin carriage, attempts of the police to intervene are blocked, singing with passion can be heard. The procession has now become Enjolras, the students, and the impassioned crowd. They turn off the main street away from the course of the funeral procession expected. As the procession is turned off, the cavalry division gallops ahead and is disappeared around a corner. Over this side street, Gavroche's elephant looms. He slips away through the barricade, which is still being risen. The final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture - her favourite sewing armchair - is pried by Grantaire from her arms and is added to the barricade. The impressive wall of the barricade is now completed: up to twelve feet high, with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Protection of the left and right side of the cafe is provided by two smaller barricades. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to his little army. Javert, still disguised as a rebel, is let back through the 'gate' which is guarded into the barricaded street. Atop the barricade, a single flaming torch, caged in by cobbles, underlights a fluttering red flag. Looking up, they all see Gavroche, on the top of the barricade. The guns are swung round by them to aim at Javert, who stares back in defiance. Javert is faced by Enjolras as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses, bore into the barricade, and several men are wounded. The red flag falls because the pole is sliced through; everyone freezes. The torch is brought by Marius closer to the powder keg, but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius descends from the barricade, and as he is surrounded by everyone in amazement, Eponine is spotted by him lying propped against the barricade. The letter is pulled out of her pocket with a struggle, and she pushes it into his hand.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Silent faces of the poor line the streets, watching as black-suited dignitaries with laurel branches pass by. In time with the drums, the crowd, including Enjolras, Marius, and radical students, begins to sing. The dignitaries notice the singing and look uneasy. A team of black horses, with nodding plumes, draws a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin reaches the students, Enjolras steps in front, waves a red flag, and halts the procession. The students break from the crowd and surround the carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and others climb on top, led by Combeferre. Police and guardsmen try to control the growing crowd, which supports the students and blocks police intervention, singing passionately. The crowd becomes the procession, turning off the main street. The cavalry division gallops ahead and vanishes around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over a side street as he slips through the rising barricade. Grantaire adds Madame Hucheloup's favorite armchair to the barricade, now a twelve-foot-high wall with a guarded section for access. Two smaller barricades protect the cafe's sides. Enjolras climbs the main barricade, addressing his army. Javert, disguised as a rebel, re-enters through the guarded gate. A flaming torch atop the barricade underlights a red flag. Gavroche stands atop the barricade as guns aim at Javert, who defies them. Enjolras confronts Javert as bullets hit the barricade, wounding several. The red flag falls, and everyone freezes. Marius approaches a powder keg, but soldiers have already retreated. He descends, and as everyone gathers around, he finds Eponine propped against the barricade. She struggles to hand him a letter from her pocket.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Silent faces of the poor watch as black-suited dignitaries with laurel branches pass by. In time with the drums, Enjolras, Marius, and radical students sing. The dignitaries notice and glance uneasily. Black horses with nodding plumes draw a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin nears, Enjolras waves a red flag, halting the procession. Students surround the coffin carriage, led by Combeferre. Police and guardsmen control the crowd, which supports the students, blocking police intervention. The crowd becomes the procession, diverting from the expected route. The cavalry gallops ahead and vanishes. Gavroche's elephant looms over a side street. Grantaire adds Madame Hucheloup's armchair to the barricade, now twelve feet high, with a guarded section for access. Two smaller barricades protect the cafe's sides. Enjolras addresses his army from the barricade. Javert, disguised as a rebel, enters through the gate. A torch underlights a red flag. Guns aim at Javert, who defies them. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets hit the barricade, wounding men. The red flag falls; everyone freezes. Marius nears a powder keg, but soldiers have left. He descends, finding Eponine, who gives him a letter.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Along the bustling streets, the silent, watchful faces of the impoverished line the sidewalks, waiting and observing intently as a solemn column of dignitaries, all dressed in formal black suits and carrying branches of laurel, solemnly passes by. Softly, in perfect harmony with the rhythmic beating of the drums, the onlookers begin to sing. Among these singers are Enjolras, Marius, and the group of radical students, their voices rising with the crowd. The dignitaries, now aware of the growing chorus, glance uneasily from side to side, their expressions betraying a sense of discomfort. Into the frame comes a team of majestic black horses, stepping slowly and deliberately, their black plumes nodding with each step. They draw behind them a gun carriage, which is draped in the vibrant tricolour flag. As the coffin, resting solemnly on its carriage, draws level with the students, Enjolras suddenly steps out boldly in front of the horses. He waves the red flag defiantly, bringing the horses and the entire procession to an abrupt halt. The students, filled with determination, break the ranks of the crowd and surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students, led by the resolute Combeferre, climb onto the top of the carriage. Meanwhile, police and national guardsmen struggle to control the swelling crowds. The crowd, in a show of support, surrounds the coffin carriage, blocking the police's attempts to intervene, their singing growing more passionate. Enjolras, the students, and the fervent crowd have now become the procession itself. They veer off the main street, diverging from the expected course of the funeral procession. As the procession turns off, a cavalry division gallops ahead, disappearing swiftly around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over this side street, a silent sentinel. He slips away through the barricade, which is still in the process of rising. Grantaire prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her reluctant arms—her cherished sewing armchair—and adds it to the growing barricade. The barricade is now complete: an imposing wall reaching up to twelve feet high, with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades stand guard, protecting the left and right sides of the café. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to address his little army. Javert, still maintaining his disguise as a rebel, is allowed back through the guarded 'gate' into the barricaded street. A single flaming torch, perched atop the barricade and caged in by cobbles, casts an eerie glow on a fluttering red flag. They all look up; there's Gavroche, perched confidently on the top of the barricade. Guns swing around, aiming at Javert, who stares back defiantly. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses, bore into the barricade, and wound several men. The red flag falls, its pole sliced through; everyone freezes in shock. Marius brings the torch closer to the powder keg, but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius descends from the barricade, and as everyone surrounds him in amazement, he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With a struggle, she pulls a letter out of her pocket and pushes it into his hand, her final act of defiance.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Amidst the lively and bustling streets teeming with activity, the silent and watchful faces of the impoverished line the crowded sidewalks. They wait patiently, observing with intense focus as a solemn and dignified column of distinguished dignitaries advances solemnly along the avenue. Each dignitary is dressed impeccably in formal black suits and carries a branch of laurel, a symbol of their honorary status, as they solemnly proceed by. Softly and gently, harmonizing perfectly with the rhythmic and steady beating of the drums, the onlookers begin to sing a chorus. Among the singers are Enjolras, Marius, and a group of passionate radical students, their voices rising in unison with the swelling crowd. The dignitaries, now becoming aware of the growing and powerful chorus surrounding them, glance uneasily from side to side, their faces betraying a palpable sense of discomfort and apprehension. Into the frame comes a majestic team of black horses, their movements slow and deliberate. The black plumes adorning their heads nod rhythmically with each step. Behind them, they draw a gun carriage, which is elegantly draped in the vibrant tricolour flag. As the coffin, resting solemnly upon its carriage, reaches the students, Enjolras steps out boldly in front of the imposing horses. He waves the red flag defiantly, bringing the horses and the entire procession to an abrupt standstill. The students, fueled by determination and resolve, break through the ranks of the crowd and encircle the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students, led by the steadfast and determined Combeferre, climb onto the top of the carriage. Meanwhile, police and national guardsmen struggle valiantly to control the swelling and increasingly uncontrollable crowds. In a show of collective support, the crowd surrounds the coffin carriage, effectively blocking the police's attempts to intervene, their passionate singing growing even more fervent. Enjolras, the students, and the fervent crowd have now become the procession itself, shifting the direction and tone. They veer off the main street, diverging boldly from the expected and traditional course of the funeral procession. As this newly redirected procession turns off, a cavalry division gallops ahead at full speed, disappearing swiftly around a corner. On this side street, Gavroche's elephant looms over the scene, a silent and imposing sentinel. He deftly slips away through the growing barricade, which remains in the process of rising to completion. Grantaire prises the final cherished piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her reluctant arms—her precious sewing armchair—and adds it meticulously to the growing and formidable barricade. The barricade now stands complete, an imposing wall reaching up to twelve feet high, with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access when necessary. Two smaller barricades stand vigilantly, protecting the left and right sides of the café. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to address his assembled little army. Javert, maintaining his disguise as a rebel, is allowed passage back through the guarded and secured 'gate' into the fortified street. Atop the barricade, a single flaming torch, caged in by cobbles, casts an eerie and flickering glow on a fluttering red flag. They all look up; there's Gavroche, standing confidently and poised on the top of the barricade. Guns swing around, their barrels aimed steadily at Javert, who returns their stares with defiant resolve. Enjolras confronts Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the surrounding houses, bore into the barricade, and wound several men. The red flag falls dramatically, its pole sliced clean through; everyone freezes in a state of shock. Marius brings the torch perilously closer to the powder keg, but already the soldiers have wisely cleared out. Marius descends from the barricade, and as everyone surrounds him in amazement and curiosity, he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. Struggling, she pulls a letter from her pocket and pushes it into his hand, her final act of defiance.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the scene unfolds along the streets, the silent faces of the poor stand in anticipation, their eyes fixed on the approaching column of black-suited dignitaries who solemnly carry branches of laurel. The dignitaries move with a measured pace, their presence commanding attention as they pass by. In synchrony with the rhythmic beating of the drums, the onlookers, including Enjolras, Marius, and the radical students, begin to softly sing, their voices gradually rising in unison. The dignitaries, now aware of the growing chorus, exchange uneasy glances, their eyes darting from side to side as they continue their procession. Into the frame, a team of black horses emerges, their steps deliberate and slow, adorned with nodding black plumes. These horses draw behind them a gun carriage, which is draped in the tricolour flag, a symbol of national pride. As the coffin on its carriage reaches the students, Enjolras makes a sudden, decisive move, stepping out in front of the horses. With a bold wave of the red flag, he brings the horses and the entire procession to an abrupt halt. In response, the students break away from the ranks of the crowd, swiftly moving to encircle the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students, led by Combeferre, climb onto the top of the carriage, asserting their presence. Meanwhile, police and national guardsmen attempt to manage the swelling crowds, but the crowd, now fully supportive of the students, surrounds the coffin carriage, their passionate singing drowning out any attempts by the police to intervene. Enjolras, the students, and the fervent crowd have now transformed into the procession itself, veering off the main street and deviating from the expected course of the funeral procession. As they turn, a cavalry division gallops ahead, quickly disappearing around a corner. In the midst of this, Gavroche's elephant looms over the side street, and he deftly slips away through the barricade, which is still in the process of being constructed. Grantaire, with determination, prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her reluctant grasp—her cherished sewing armchair—and adds it to the growing barricade. The barricade now stands complete, an imposing wall reaching up to twelve feet high, with a heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades flank the left and right sides of the cafe, providing additional protection. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade, turning to address his assembled little army. Javert, still maintaining his disguise as a rebel, is permitted to re-enter the barricaded street through the guarded 'gate.' Atop the barricade, a single flaming torch, encaged by cobbles, casts an eerie glow on the fluttering red flag. All eyes turn upward to see Gavroche perched on the top of the barricade. Guns swing around, their barrels trained on Javert, who meets their gaze with defiant resolve. Enjolras confronts Javert as bullets begin to ricochet off the cornices of the surrounding houses, embedding themselves into the barricade and wounding several men. The red flag, a symbol of their cause, falls as its pole is sliced through, causing a momentary freeze among the participants. Marius, with a sense of urgency, brings the torch closer to the powder keg, but the soldiers have already retreated. Descending from the barricade, Marius is surrounded by the astonished crowd, and in that moment, he notices Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With visible effort, she retrieves a letter from her pocket and presses it into his hand, her gesture laden with significance.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Along the streets, silent faces of the poor watch as a column of black-suited dignitaries carrying laurel branches passes by. In time with the drums, the crowd, including Enjolras, Marius, and the radical students, begins to sing, drawing uneasy glances from the dignitaries. A team of black horses, adorned with nodding plumes, slowly approaches, pulling a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin reaches the students, Enjolras steps forward, waves the red flag, and halts the procession. The students break from the crowd, surround the coffin carriage, and climb atop it, led by Combeferre. The crowd supports them, blocking police intervention and singing passionately. Enjolras and the students, now leading the procession, divert from the main street. A cavalry division gallops ahead and vanishes around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over a side street as he slips through the rising barricade. Grantaire adds Madame Hucheloup's favorite armchair to complete the barricade, forming an impressive twelve-foot-high wall with a guarded section for access. Two smaller barricades protect the cafe's sides. Enjolras climbs the main barricade and addresses his army. Javert, disguised as a rebel, is allowed back through the guarded gate. A single flaming torch atop the barricade illuminates a fluttering red flag. They look up to see Gavroche on the barricade as guns aim at Javert, who stares defiantly. Enjolras confronts Javert amid ricocheting bullets that wound several men. The red flag falls as the pole is sliced through, freezing everyone. Marius approaches the powder keg with a torch, but the soldiers have already retreated. Descending from the barricade, Marius finds Eponine propped against it. She struggles to hand him a letter from her pocket.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
Along the streets of Paris, silent faces of the poor wait and watch as a column of black-suited dignitaries carrying branches of laurel, an ancient symbol of victory and honor, passes by. Softly, in time with the drums echoing through the narrow avenues, the watching people begin to sing, among them Enjolras, Marius, and the radical students of the Friends of the ABC, a group pushing for revolutionary change. The dignitaries become aware of the singing and glance uneasily from side to side, conscious of the city's volatile political climate. Into frame comes a team of black horses stepping slowly, black plumes nodding in somber rhythm, drawing behind them a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag, representing liberty, equality, and fraternity—the ideals of the French Revolution.

As the coffin on its carriage draws level with the students, Enjolras suddenly steps out in front of the horses and waves the red flag, a symbol of revolutionary socialism, stopping the horses and the procession. The students break the ranks of the crowd and surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras, Marius, Courfeyrac, and other students, following their charismatic leader Combeferre, climb onto the top of the carriage. Police and national guardsmen, wary of the growing unrest, attempt to control the crowds. The crowd, fueled by revolutionary fervor, supports them and surrounds the coffin carriage, blocking the police's attempts to intervene, singing with passion as though in chorus with historical echo.

Enjolras, the students, and the impassioned crowd have now become the procession. They turn off the main street away from the expected course of the funeral procession, a protest against the ruling powers. As the procession turns off, the cavalry division gallops ahead and disappears around a corner, possibly to regroup and strategize against the insurrection. Gavroche's elephant—an abandoned monument in the shape of an elephant in the Place de la Bastille—looms over this side street. He slips away through the barricade, which is still rising, a symbol of resistance. Grantaire prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her arms—her favourite sewing armchair—and adds it to the barricade. The barricade is now complete: an impressive wall up to twelve feet high, reminiscent of the defenses seen during historical sieges, with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades protect the left and right side of the cafe, Les Amis' meeting place.

Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to his little army. Javert, still in his disguise as a rebel infiltrator, is let back through the guarded 'gate' into the barricaded street. A single flaming torch atop the barricade, caged in by cobbles, underlights a fluttering red flag. They all look up; there's Gavroche, on the top of the barricade, embodying the spirit of youthful rebellion. Guns swing round to aim at Javert, who stares back in defiance, aware of the danger but unfazed. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses built from old Parisian limestone, bore into the barricade, and wound several men. The red flag falls, the pole sliced through, a symbolic moment of pause for the revolutionaries; everyone freezes. Marius brings the torch closer to the powder keg, threatening to ignite a violent response, but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius comes down from the barricade, and as everyone surrounds him in amazement, he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With a struggle, she pulls the letter out of her pocket—an important message with the potential to alter fates—and pushes it into his hand.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: Along the streets silent faces of the poor wait and watch as a column of blacksuited dignitaries carrying branches of laurel passes by. Softly in time with the drums the watching people begin to sing among them Enjolras Marius and the radical students. The dignitaries become aware of the singing and glance uneasily from side to side. Into frame comes a team of black horses stepping slowly black plumes nodding drawing behind them a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin on its carriage draws level with the students Enjolras suddenly steps out in front of the horses waves the red flag and stops the horses and the procession. The students break the ranks of the crowd and surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras Marius Courfeyrac and other students climb onto the top of the carriage led by Combeferre. Police and national guardsmen control the growing crowds. The crowd supports them and surrounds the coffin carriage blocking the police's attempts to intervene singing with passion. Enjolras the students and the impassioned crowd have now become the procession. They turn off the main street away from the expected course of the funeral procession. As the procession turns off the cavalry division gallops ahead and disappears around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over this side street. He slips away through the barricade which is still rising. Grantaire prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her arms  her favourite sewing armchair  and adds it to the barricade. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. The barricade is now complete. an impressive wall up to twelve feet high with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades protect the left and right side of the cafe. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to his little army. Javert still in his disguise as a rebel is let back through the guarded 'gate' into the barricaded street. A single flaming torch atop the barricade caged in by cobbles underlights a fluttering red flag. They all look up. there is Gavroche on the top of the barricade. Guns swing round to aim at Javert who stares back in defiance. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses bore into the barricade and wound several men. The red flag falls the pole sliced through. everyone freezes. Marius brings the torch closer to the powder keg but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius comes down from the barricade and as everyone surrounds him in amazement he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With a struggle she pulls the letter out of her pocket and pushes it into his hand.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Along the streets silent faces of the poor wait and watch as a column of blacksuited dignitaries carrying branches of laurel passes by. Softly in time with the drums the watching people begin to sing among them Enjolras Marius and the radical students. The dignitaries become aware of the singing and glance uneasily from side to side. Into frame comes a team of black horses stepping slowly black plumes nodding drawing behind them a gun carriage draped in the tricolour flag. As the coffin on its carriage draws level with the students Enjolras suddenly steps out in front of the horses waves the red flag and stops the horses and the procession. The students break the ranks of the crowd and surround the coffin carriage. Enjolras Marius Courfeyrac and other students climb onto the top of the carriage led by Combeferre. Police and national guardsmen control the growing crowds. The crowd supports them and surrounds the coffin carriage blocking the police's attempts to intervene singing with passion. Enjolras the students and the impassioned crowd have now become the procession. They turn off the main street away from the expected course of the funeral procession. As the procession turns off the cavalry division gallops ahead and disappears around a corner. Gavroche's elephant looms over this side street. He slips away through the barricade which is still rising. Grantaire prises the final piece of Madame Hucheloup's furniture from her arms  her favourite sewing armchair  and adds it to the barricade. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. The barricade is now complete. an impressive wall up to twelve feet high with one heavily guarded section that can be wheeled open to allow access. Two smaller barricades protect the left and right side of the cafe. Enjolras climbs halfway up the main barricade and turns to his little army. Javert still in his disguise as a rebel is let back through the guarded 'gate' into the barricaded street. A single flaming torch atop the barricade caged in by cobbles underlights a fluttering red flag. They all look up. there is Gavroche on the top of the barricade. Guns swing round to aim at Javert who stares back in defiance. Enjolras faces Javert as bullets ricochet off the cornices of the houses bore into the barricade and wound several men. The red flag falls the pole sliced through. everyone freezes. Marius brings the torch closer to the powder keg but already the soldiers have cleared out. Marius comes down from the barricade and as everyone surrounds him in amazement he spots Eponine lying propped against the barricade. With a struggle she pulls the letter out of her pocket and pushes it into his hand.

With a struggle she pulls the letter out of her pocket and pushes it into his hand.

Softly in time with the drums the watching people begin to sing among them Enjolras Marius and the radical students. The dignitaries become aware of the singing and glance uneasily from side to side. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Across the meadows, whispering shadows of the wealthy flutter and grumble as a band of red-robed acrobats juggling pineapples glides past. Loudly, in rhythm with the flutes, the grumbling shadows start to dance, among them Thibault, Sylvain, and the wandering poets. The acrobats notice the dancing and shuffle awkwardly forward and back. Into view trots a flock of white doves flying quickly, blue ribbons fluttering, pulling behind them a cart filled with pumpkins draped in the rainbow tapestry. As the basket on its cart aligns with the poets, Thibault unexpectedly leaps before the doves, twirls the blue scarf, and halts the doves and the parade. The poets scatter the edges of the flock and enclose the pumpkin cart. Thibault, Sylvain, Auguste, and other poets ascend onto the top of the cart, led by François. Firefighters and park rangers manage the thinning flock. The flock cheers them and encloses the pumpkin cart, hampering the firefighters' efforts to assist, dancing with fervor. Thibault, the poets, and the fervent flock have now become the parade. They veer onto the side path away from the anticipated trail of the harvest parade. As the parade veers off, the biker brigade zooms past and vanishes around a hill. Celeste's balloon towers over this narrow path. She sneaks away through the thicket, which is still growing. Étienne wrests the last fragment of Madame Armand's tapestry from her grasp - her cherished knitting stool - and adds it to the thicket. The thicket is now whole: a towering hedge up to twenty feet tall, with one lightly patrolled section that can be swung ajar for entry. Two tinier hedges guard the front and back side of the bistro. Thibault scales partway up the main hedge and addresses his small troupe. Armand, still in his costume as a jester, is allowed back through the patrolled 'door' into the hedged path. A solitary glowing lantern atop the hedge, surrounded by bricks, illuminates a fluttering sapphire scarf. They all gaze upward; there's Celeste, on the crest of the hedge. Drums pivot round to focus on Armand, who glares back with pride. Thibault challenges Armand as arrows deflect off the rooftops of the cottages, pierce the hedge, and injure several birds. The sapphire scarf descends, the rod severed; everyone halts. Sylvain advances the lantern nearer to the basket of fruit, but already the hunters have wandered off. Sylvain descends from the hedge, and as everyone encircles him with wonder, he spots Caroline resting tilted against the hedge. With difficulty, she extracts the note from her satchel and hands it to him.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: In the streets, silent onlookers, including Enjolras, Marius, and radical students, watch black-suited dignitaries pass by. The students sing softly, causing unease among the dignitaries, and as a coffin draped in the tricolour flag passes, Enjolras halts the procession with a red flag. The students and crowd surround the coffin, transforming into a new procession diverging from the expected route. As cavalry rides ahead, Gavroche and others bolster a barricade with furniture, creating an imposing twelve-foot wall. Enjolras addresses his group, and disguised Javert re-enters the barricaded area. A torch highlights the red flag, with Gavroche atop the barricade. Guns aim at Javert as bullets fly, but the red flag falls, halting everyone. Marius approaches a powder keg, but soldiers have retreated. He then discovers Eponine against the barricade, who hands him a letter with difficulty.
